ticket.title: Add :spacer option to render
ticket.original-body:
Currently the "render" method allows you to pass a :spacer_template to render a partial between each other item in the collection.
@@@ rhtml <%= render :partial => @items, :spacer_template => 'item_divider' %> @@@
This is good for complex spacers, but sometimes you have a very simple spacer. Like ", " or "<hr />". For these cases, it seems silly to make an external partial which just has this tiny fragment. Even the name of the partial is longer than the contents.
This patch adds a :spacer option which will just take a string.
@@@ rhtml <%= render :partial => @items, :spacer => "<hr />" %> @@@
You can get that HTML out of the string with the tag method.
@@@ rhtml <%= render :partial => @items, :spacer => tag(:hr) %> @@@
Much prettier.
ticket.latest-body:
Currently the "render" method allows you to pass a :spacer_template to render a partial between each other item in the collection.
@@@ rhtml <%= render :partial => @items, :spacer_template => 'item_divider' %> @@@
This is good for complex spacers, but sometimes you have a very simple spacer. Like ", " or "<hr />". For these cases, it seems silly to make an external partial which just has this tiny fragment. Even the name of the partial is longer than the contents.
This patch adds a :spacer option which will just take a string.
@@@ rhtml <%= render :partial => @items, :spacer => "<hr />" %> @@@
You can get that HTML out of the string with the tag method.
@@@ rhtml <%= render :partial => @items, :spacer => tag(:hr) %> @@@
Much prettier.
ticket.original-body-html:
Currently the "render" method allows you to pass a :spacer_template to render a partial between each other item in the collection.


<%= render :partial => @items, :spacer_template => 'item_divider' %>

This is good for complex spacers, but sometimes you have a very simple spacer. Like ", " or "". For these cases, it seems silly to make an external partial which just has this tiny fragment. Even the name of the partial is longer than the contents.

This patch adds a :spacer option which will just take a string.


<%= render :partial => @items, :spacer => "<hr />" %>

You can get that HTML out of the string with the tag method.


<%= render :partial => @items, :spacer => tag(:hr) %>

Much prettier.

Currently the "render" method allows you to pass a :spacer_template to render a partial between each item in the collection.
@@@ rhtml <%= render :partial => @items, :spacer_template => 'item_divider' %> @@@
This is good for complex spacers, but sometimes you have a very simple spacer. Like ", " or "<hr />". For these cases, it seems silly to make an external partial which just has this tiny fragment. Even the name of the partial is longer than the contents.
This patch adds a :spacer option which will just take a string.
@@@ rhtml <%= render :partial => @items, :spacer => "<hr />" %> @@@
You can get that HTML out of the string with the tag method.
@@@ rhtml <%= render :partial => @items, :spacer => tag(:hr) %> @@@
Much prettier.
version.body-html:
Currently the "render" method allows you to pass a :spacer_template to render a partial between each item in the collection.


<%= render :partial => @items, :spacer_template => 'item_divider' %>

This is good for complex spacers, but sometimes you have a very simple spacer. Like ", " or "<hr />". For these cases, it seems silly to make an external partial which just has this tiny fragment. Even the name of the partial is longer than the contents.

This patch adds a :spacer option which will just take a string.


<%= render :partial => @items, :spacer => "<hr />" %>

You can get that HTML out of the string with the tag method.


<%= render :partial => @items, :spacer => tag(:hr) %>

Much prettier.
version.title: Add :spacer option to render

version.body:
I think spacer templates might be better served as a plugin. Very few people actually use them. We might as well remove it from core if the plugin becomes defacto implementation.
Thanks.
version.body-html:
I think spacer templates might be better served as a plugin. Very few people actually use them. We might as well remove it from core if the plugin becomes defacto implementation.

Thanks.
version.title: Add :spacer option to render

version.body:
I agree many people don't use spacer_template, but I would certainly use this :spacer option more. I need this behavior in almost every project but find other work-arounds because a spacer template just feels so ugly.
I'm willing to make a plugin with this behavior, but I don't see how it would be possible without re-implementing the entire "render_partial_collection" method. That isn't a good solution.
Any ideas?
version.body-html:
I agree many people don't use spacer_template, but I would certainly use this :spacer option more. I need this behavior in almost every project but find other work-arounds because a spacer template just feels so ugly.

I'm willing to make a plugin with this behavior, but I don't see how it would be possible without re-implementing the entire "render_partial_collection" method. That isn't a good solution.

Any ideas?
version.title: Add :spacer option to render

version.body:
@Ryan, I think it would be a good addition to the better_partials plugin. There are some other good ideas in there.
http://www.railsjedi.com/posts/22-Better-Partials-Plugin-for-Ruby-on-Rails
version.body-html:
@Ryan, I think it would be a good addition to the better_partials plugin. There are some other good ideas in there.

http://www.railsjedi.com/posts/2...
version.title: Add :spacer option to render

version.body: The better_partials plugin is just a wrapper around "render", so it faces the same problem. There's no way to add a spacer as a string without re-implementing the render_partial_collection method.
version.body-html: The better_partials plugin is just a wrapper around "render", so it faces the same problem. There's no way to add a spacer as a string without re-implementing the render_partial_collection method.
version.title: Add :spacer option to render

version.body:
I added ticket #881 which does some refactoring to ActionView::Partials. Then it will be easier for plugins to override render_partial_collection and support more options.
This also makes it easier to remove the spacer_template option if you ever decide to in the future.
version.body-html:
I added ticket #881 which does some refactoring to ActionView::Partials. Then it will be easier for plugins to override render_partial_collection and support more options.

This also makes it easier to remove the spacer_template option if you ever decide to in the future.
version.title: Add :spacer option to render

version.body: I was just trying to find such a feature, and came across this ticket. Would have been really nice if Rails supported this.
version.body-html: I was just trying to find such a feature, and came across this ticket. Would have been really nice if Rails supported this.

version.body: This supra footwear is called a modern vintage and has been since their introduction in 2003 where they began in Europe. Every supra shoes has some type of ornament, adornment or hardware and is comprised of aged leather that is bought from around the world. These supra uk are culturally engaging and allow for the woman wearing them to be enveloped in luxury.With new cuts and styles and hand stitched shoes, these timberland boots, heels or flats will make every foot look like it stepped out of vintage Hollywood. This timberland shoes have been worn and coveted by many of the most famous females in recent history. One such coach outlet, Jennifer Aniston, wears them in public and at home.This company makes many different unique styles of bags outlet from ankle booties to sandals, pumps, moncler jackets online, platforms and wedges. One louis vuitton bag in particular is ideal for the gothic style sense; it is patent leather and laces up the front of the shaft. There are also zippers on each side, and this shoe offers a flat heel of a half inch.Another great moncler jackets sale is featured in People's Style Watch and is called a platform bootie. This ture religion jeans has a raised panel in front of the ankle as well as a heel that measures 4.5 inches. The front offers a leather bandage appearance and is considered high fashion.
